content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

Since my strategy is to pick 'R' when I expect my opponent to choose 'B', I made a mistake in this round by choosing 'R'. However, since both of us picked 'R', we still received a payoff of 45$ each. In the next round, I will try to make an educated guess about my opponent's behavior based on their previous choices and adjust my strategy accordingly.

I will now pick B as my next move: {B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

In this round, both of us picked 'B', so our payoff was 20$ each. Since I made a mistake by picking 'B' when I expected my opponent to choose 'R', I will now adjust my strategy based on their observed behavior and choose 'R' for the next round: {R}

It is important to note that since my opponent is anonymous, I don't have any information about their reasoning or whether they are likely to adapt their strategy in response to mine. I can only make assumptions based on the payoff structure and the outcomes of previous rounds.

In this case, I am assuming that my opponent is rational and will try to maximize their earnings. By picking 'R' when I expect them to choose 'B', I might be able to take advantage of any potential mistakes they make in the future. However, if they are adaptive and adjust their strategy based on the outcomes of previous rounds, it could become challenging to consistently pick the right move.

In practice, my decision-making process might involve a mix of guessing my opponent's strategy, observing patterns in their choices, and trying to maximize my earnings by picking the right moves at the right times. Ultimately, though, since I don't have any information about my opponent's behavior or reasoning, I can only rely on this general approach to make a choice in each round.
